Friday, 23. September 2022

BlockWallet

Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMartin Lecam, Front-End Developer

Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMartin Lecam, Front-End Developer #16‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis is the sixteenth post in our ‚ÄúMeet our new hire‚Äù series, where we introduce you to the latest additions to our team here at BlockWallet. We‚Äôd like to our latest team member, Martin Lecam! Martin is a talented front-end developer that brings his versatile experience from working in various industries. And now, he‚Äôs bringing his expe
Meet our new hire‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäMartin Lecam, Front-End Developer

#16‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäThis is the sixteenth post in our ‚ÄúMeet our new hire‚Äù series, where we introduce you to the latest additions to our team here at BlockWallet.

We‚Äôd like to our latest team member, Martin Lecam! Martin is a talented front-end developer that brings his versatile experience from working in various industries. And now, he‚Äôs bringing his expertise to BlockWallet‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähelping the team continuously improve our premium user experience.

What‚Äôs your job position?

I‚Äôm a Front-End developer that is helping construct the BlockWallet browser extension. My background consists of being a full-stack developer, but I wanted to focus on Front-End to improve my knowledge of blockchain technology‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBlockWallet gives me this opportunity. I‚Äôm someone who seeks challenges which is why I decided to join BlockWallet!

How long have you worked as a developer?

I‚Äôve been working as a developer for more than 8 years. I started as an intern and then became a full-stack developer. I also had the opportunity of working as an RPA developer for an oil company, we were asked to create automations for the finance team. These automations included copying human actions in the computer, downloading files, and making calculations. After those calculations were done our automations pushed that data back to the system.

Which projects have you worked on before?

I started as an intern in a SaaS company and worked there for 5 years. My role there was as a full-stack developer consisting of front-end/back-end work. It also gave me the opportunity of visiting customers and presenting our product‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsomething that really helped my communication skills. In this company, I worked with a SaaS system and also contributed in the first offline product, designed for companies who have limited internet access.

After my full-stack developer position in the SaaS company, I worked as an RPA developer for an oil company. In this experience, I learned a lot about the oil business and finance.

My most recent position was at a bank working as a Python developer‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI was assigned to create end-of-day reports that indicated profit and losses for traders. Overall, this was a really exciting job since it was my first time as a Python developer.

When did you first get involved in crypto?

I first got involved in crypto about a year ago, messing around with the basics. What really intrigued me with this space, was the fundamental concept of crypto. Particularly with decentralized finance, and how we could take ownership of our own financial assets. And after some time I started ‚Äòplaying‚Äô with crypto to learn about it, which is what ultimately led me to get this job.

What made you interested in BlockWallet?

The first thing that made me interested in BlockWallet was the idea of preserving privacy in a decentralized ecosystem. By simply having someone‚Äôs wallet address, you are able to track their entire Web3 footprint due to the transparent nature of the blockchain. And while there are certain levels of transparency we cannot avoid, BlockWallet provides the tools to help remain private on public chains.

The second thing was the team. After doing a couple of interviews, I quickly realized the quality of people that are working here and I knew it was going to be a great experience.

Accepting the offer was a no-brainer. Cutting-edge privacy technology, a fantastic team, and the opportunity to work in Web3.

Why do you think privacy matters on blockchains?

Privacy is vital in each aspect of our life, so why should be different in Web3? In fact, it should matter more because of how your entire financial history is accessible on the blockchain. If someone can link your wallet address to your actual identity, it‚Äôs equivalent to accessing your entire bank account history!

Do you have any predictions on where crypto will be 5 years from now?

5 years from now, I believe crypto technology will be engrained into every part of our lives. Even for the ones that don‚Äôt believe in crypto or think it‚Äôs a scam. It‚Äôll be similar to the internet where you don‚Äôt have a choice‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeverything will be built on blockchains.

Parting thoughts

I‚Äôm really happy to be part of the BlockWallet team and the amazing community that we‚Äôve built. I can‚Äôt wait to see what the future holds.

About BlockWallet

BlockWallet is a privacy-first self-custodial browser extension wallet where you can store, send or receive crypto and interact with your favorite blockchain apps privately.

As crypto sees mainstream adoption, blockchain‚Äôs lack of privacy often translates to security risks. BlockWallet is here to ensure that on-chain privacy does not lag behind. The wallet provides a set of advanced privacy tools wrapped in a familiar and user-friendly wallet experience, eliminating friction and making privacy accessible for everyone.

BlockWallet protects you and ensures privacy by default. When you make transactions or interact with blockchain apps, BlockWallet routes all node requests through Privacy Proxies, which mask the IP address and other metadata, that can be used to identify and track you on a blockchain. BlockWallet offers integrated Flash-Bot Protection, shielding you from sandwich attacks when you trade on DEXes. Meanwhile, the Phishing Protection feature helps you combat phishing scams by generating unique artwork on all sensitive pages.

BlockWallet is not a compromise. It‚Äôs privacy-first, but it still packs all features you would expect from a wallet. With full Web 3.0 support, the wallet allows you to connect to any DApp.

Become a part of the BlockWallet community today:

Homepage | Medium | Twitter | Telegram | Discord | GitHub | E-mail

Epicenter Podcast

Hyung Lee: Crescent Network ‚Äì The Hybrid AMM/Orderbook Decentralized Exchange

Crescent is an AMM/Orderbook Hybrid Decentralized Exchange that allows trading inter-chain assets in a cost-efficient manner. Crescent is a sovereign Cosmos chain that was created after migrating the Gravity Dex from the Cosmos Hub. Crescent particularly focuses on efficient use of liquidity by giving powerful tools to market makers to use their capital and provide good prices for traders. We we

Crescent is an AMM/Orderbook Hybrid Decentralized Exchange that allows trading inter-chain assets in a cost-efficient manner. Crescent is a sovereign Cosmos chain that was created after migrating the Gravity Dex from the Cosmos Hub. Crescent particularly focuses on efficient use of liquidity by giving powerful tools to market makers to use their capital and provide good prices for traders.

We were joined by the founder of Crescent Network, Hyung Lee, to chat about his involvement in the Cosmos ecosystem, B Harvest, the Gravity DEX, and combining AMMs and orderbooks. We also hear about Crescent's roadmap and future role within the ecosystem.

Topics covered in this episode:

Hyung's background and how he got into crypto and the Cosmos ecosystem Launching Crescent on its own chain The vision for Crescent's role within the ecosystem Liquidity formation for the project Comparing AMM and orderbooks and the advantages/disadvantages of each How AMM and orderbooks have been combined The future of AMMs Difference between a market maker and a liquidity provider Cross chain dex aggregation MEV and the interchain world

Episode links:

The Crescent Ethos Crescent Network Crescent on Twitter Hyung on Twitter

Sponsors:

Omni: Access all of Web3 in one easy-to-use wallet! Earn and manage assets at once with Omni's built-in staking, yield vaults, bridges, swaps and NFT support.
https://omni.app/ -

This episode is hosted by Brian Fabian Crain & Felix Lutsch. Show notes and listening options: epicenter.tv/462

Verida

Verida Vault Designers Win Prestigious Red Dot Award

reddot winner 2022: interface design Web2, even with all its problems, got a lot of things right. It set the tone for a high standard of User Experience (UX). For the masses to move over to Web3, we need to mirror what people have come to expect from online: smooth, stunning, enjoyable experiences. Given the technical world of Web3 with its own language of acronyms, memes and slang, simplified des
reddot winner 2022: interface design

Web2, even with all its problems, got a lot of things right. It set the tone for a high standard of User Experience (UX). For the masses to move over to Web3, we need to mirror what people have come to expect from online: smooth, stunning, enjoyable experiences.

Given the technical world of Web3 with its own language of acronyms, memes and slang, simplified design is more important than ever. Excited, Verida‚Äôs design agency, winning the Red Dot Award is a step forward in making Web3 more accessible and accepted.

The coveted Red Dot

The Red Dot Design Award is an international design competition that best distinguishes business activities through excellent design. The award is judged on three disciplines: Product Design, Communication Design, and Design Concept.

Running since 1955, the award originally highlighted works in industrial design. As the design world has evolved, so has the award. Today, it celebrates new expertise such as UX and UI design. The esteemed winners are deemed the best in the business.

The Verida Vault The award-winning Verida Vault design

Excited, a product design agency based in Ukraine, have worked with Verida since 2019. Their two main projects include designing the website and Verida Vault‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthe work that won them the coveted 2022 Red Dot.

‚ÄúThe judges look for work with consumer appeal‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääan interesting design approach, a problem worth solving or something that looks new and unique,‚Äù said Oleksandr Perelotov, Excited‚Äôs Design Director and Co-Founder.

Perelotov said there was a strong education piece involved in designing Web3 products.

‚ÄúThis is still very new technology. It was different from designing an e-commerce project, where there‚Äôs an abundance of examples. What we found helpful was putting real-life examples to abstract ideas. For example, while envisioning the data requests or data sharing, we created a Covid vaccination certificate.‚Äù

Designing to solve real-world problems and improve the lives of end users obviously worked. We share this sentiment at Verida.

Enjoyable, personalized online experiences

Our mission is to empower users to own and control their personal data. To transfer the power from institutions to individuals. It‚Äôs not just an era where data is consensual and self-sovereign.

We‚Äôre building on this to create new products and services to enhance our lives through wonderful, hyper-personalized digital experiences.

To achieve this, Web3 apps need to offer the standard of UX that people are used to today. Excited gets this‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou can see it in their designs.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an honor to have our name and blockchain data wallet attached to such a notable award. We hope Excited‚Äôs incredible design work sets the tone for bold, beautiful, yet friendly and non-threatening UX/UI in Web3,‚Äù said Verida CEO, Chris Were.

This is the fourth Red Dot Award for Excited. The agency won the 2022 and 2021 Interface Design category and took home two awards in 2020 for Corporate Design and Identity, and Brand Design and Identity.

The Excited team Get started with the Verida Vault

The Verida Vault is now available to download from the iOS App Store and Google Play Store.

Learn more about the Verida Vault and get started:

Verida Getting Started Guide Vault User Guides Vault Video Guides

Verida Vault Designers Win Prestigious Red Dot Award was originally published in Verida on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

00:50 • a day ago

Thursday, 22. September 2022

Nym - Medium

Tokenomics Update for NYM Token

An update on the tokenomics of the Nym mixnet. Nym is a decentralised privacy mixnet. The Nym mixnet has an associated NYM utility token that grants usage rights to the privacy network. The tokenomics of the Nym mixnet is intended to incentivise people to provide privacy, rather than surveillance. Not only that, the tokenomics has been designed and engineered to incentivise good priva

An update on the tokenomics of the Nym mixnet.

Nym is a decentralised privacy mixnet. The Nym mixnet has an associated NYM utility token that grants usage rights to the privacy network.

The tokenomics of the Nym mixnet is intended to incentivise people to provide privacy, rather than surveillance.

Not only that, the tokenomics has been designed and engineered to incentivise good privacy protections: the better the service in terms of mixing packets, the better the reputation of a mix node in Nym will be in the overall infrastructure. In essence, Nym serves a ‚Äòreputation‚Äô token for mixnetworks.

Recap on token milestones

A total supply of one billion NYM tokens was generated on the decentralised mainnet Nyx chain in February 2022. The NYM token comes in two flavours: Native tokens on the Cosmos ecosystem (used within the privacy infra) and ERC20 tokens - as much software does not include support for Cosmos, so a bridge allows them to be ‚Äòwrapped‚Äô as ERC tokens. Transfer between the two versions is done via Gravity Bridge. Currently 50M tokens are ERC20.

On 9 February 2022, 75M NYM was listed on CoinList and the tokens were issued on 14 April 2022.

The NYM token is now listed on several exchanges‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsee full list here.

Launch until now

The NYM mainnet was launched in January 2022 with a healthy 480 nodes operating as of now (240 nodes per epoch). Applications via Nym Connect are available here. Staking is enabled and approximately 40M tokens are currently staked.

Since the Mainnet release approximately 3M tokens have been distributed from the mixmining pool to our worldwide community of mix node operators (vs the budget of approximately 20M tokens).

The first tranche of team and investor tokens were distributed in August 2022. While we have seen a healthy increase in staking resulting from the release of liquid tokens, we have so far been able to keep the staking parameters the same, subject to weekly reviews.

Recent industry happenings

Wintermute is one of the market-neutral market-makers that focus on NYM tokens. While there was an interruption to Wintermute services due to a hack that led to some real problems the last few days, as of 21 September, everything is back in order and stabilised. The Ethereum Merge was successfully completed on 15 September. There was a short pause on Gravity Bridge where ERC20 NYM tokens were not able to be bridged to Cosmos SDK and vice versa.

We understand that our community has asked for a regular update on the circulating supply. Please note that we are working on making an endpoint available to external service providers and will provide more updates.

Take note

No one should purchase NYM tokens for financial gain or speculation. NYM tokens should only be used within the Nym mixnet. Again, NYM is a utility token not a general purpose payment mechanism nor cryptocurrency. For investment purposes, do not use NYM tokens but instead look into other investment vehicles.

NYM tokens are required to use the mixnet or run a mix node. Check your delegations to see how the mix node is performing. If your nodes are over-saturated, you might want to redelegate! More on how to select a mix node delegate here.

This is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy, nor shall there be any sale of, Tokens to any U.S. Person or in the United States or in any other jurisdiction in which such offer, solicitation, or sale would be unlawful prior to registration or qualification under the laws of any such jurisdiction.

We are always looking for new community members to run nodes and create privacy-enhanced applications on top of Nym. Join our community to participate and keep up to date:

Discord

Twitter

Telegram

Essential links

Tokenomics FAQ

Nym on CoinList

The Nym architecture

Nym Whitepaper

Nym Github

Nym Docs

Tokenomics Update for NYM Token was originally published in nymtech on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

17:38 • a day ago

Sequoia

Sam Bankman-Fried Spotlight

The post Sam Bankman-Fried Spotlight appeared first on Sequoia Capital US/Europe.
Sam Bankman-Fried Has a Savior Complex‚ÄîAnd Maybe You Should Too

By Adam Fisher

Photography: SASHA ARUTYUNOVA

Published September 22, 2022

The founder of FTX lives his life by a calculus of altruistic impact.

Listen to this article

Every startup has a startup story. Apple was two hackers in a Los Altos garage. Google was two grad students in a Stanford dorm room. Alameda Research was just one guy in a Berkeley apartment, making a single cryptocurrency trade. That guy was Sam Bankman-Fried, or SBF to his friends. Yet the trade he made, which eventually led to the crypto-trading platform FTX, is far from the standard Silicon Valley creation tale. In 2017, when he was merely 25, SBF collapsed the so-called kimchi premium, an anomalous delta between the price of Bitcoin in much of Asia and its price in the rest of the world. It was a daring feat of arbitrage‚ÄîSBF is the only trader known to have pulled this off in any meaningful way‚Äîone which quickly made him a billionaire and achieved the status of legend.

Among Wall Street‚Äôs financial elite, SBF‚Äôs Bitcoin arb is mentioned in the same hushed tones as Paul Tudor Jones‚Äôs 1987 shorting of the entire American economy, or George Soros‚Äôs 1992 raid on the Bank of England, or John Paulson‚Äôs 2008 bet against subprime mortgages. Alameda‚Äôs capture of the kimchi premium (and other trades like it) gave SBF the grubstake he needed for his next move: founding the crypto exchange FTX‚Äîa company that  may very well end up creating the dominant all-in-one financial super-app of the future. Nothing is a sure bet in crypto, but just the possibility that FTX could join‚Äîor even eclipse‚Äîthe big four of American banking (JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Citibank) means it‚Äôs already valued at $32 billion. SBF himself has amassed more wealth in a shorter period of time than anyone else, ever. The 2022 Forbes Billionaires List pegs SBF‚Äôs net worth at $24 billion. He‚Äôs now 30 years old. But we get ahead of ourselves.

SBF learned to trade at Jane Street, an under-the-radar high-frequency trading shop in New York‚Äôs financial district. The firm recruits from the smartest students in math and physics at MIT. SBF, a physics major at MIT, had interned at Jane Street in the summer of 2013 and was one of the few such recruits invited back for a full-time job. He was put to work as a market maker trading global ETFs‚Äîmore difficult than simply making a market for a single stock, in the same way Tri-Dimensional Chess is more difficult than the bog-standard variety.

Not long before interning at Jane Street, SBF had a meeting with Will MacAskill, a young Oxford-educated philosopher who was then just completing his PhD. Over lunch at the Au Bon Pain outside Harvard Square, MacAskill laid out the principles of effective altruism (EA). The math, MacAskill argued, means that if one‚Äôs goal is to optimize one‚Äôs life for doing good, often most good can be done by choosing to make the most money possible‚Äîin order to give it all away. ‚ÄúEarn to give,‚Äù urged MacAskill.

EA traces its roots to philosopher Peter Singer, who reasons from the utilitarian point of view that the purpose of life is to maximize the well-being of others. Singer, in his eighth decade, may well be the most-read living philosopher. In the 1970s, Singer almost single-handedly created the animal rights movement, popularizing veganism as an ethical solution to the moral horror of meat. Today he‚Äôs best known for the drowning-child thought experiment. (What would you do if you came across a young child drowning in a pond?) Singer states the obvious‚Äîand then universalizes the underlying principle: ‚ÄúFew could stand by and watch a child drown; many can ignore the avoidable deaths of children in Africa or India. The question, however, is not what we usually do, but what we ought to do.‚Äù In a nutshell, Singer argues that it‚Äôs a moral imperative of the world‚Äôs well-off to give as much as possible‚Äî10, 20, even 50 percent of all income‚Äîto better the lives of the world‚Äôs poor.

MacAskill‚Äôs contribution is to combine Singer‚Äôs moral logic with the logic of finance and investment. One not only has an obligation to give a significant percentage of income away, MacAskill argues, but to give it away as efficiently as possible. And, since every charity claiming to save lives has a budget, they can all be ranked by cost-effectiveness. So, how much does it cost for a charity to save a single life? The data says that controlling the spread of malaria and worms has the biggest bang for the buck, with a life saved per every $2,000 invested. Effective altruism prioritizes this low-hanging fruit‚Äîthese are the drowning children we‚Äôre morally obligated to save first.

Effective Altruism founder will macaskill

Though EA originated at Oxford, it has found most of its traction in the Bay Area. Such fixtures in the Silicon Valley firmament as Dustin Moskovitz and Reid Hoffman have publicly endorsed the idea, as have tech oracles like Eric Drexler and Aubrey de Grey. The EA rank and file draws from the rationalist movement, a loose intellectual confederation of scruffy, young STEM-oriented freethinkers who typically (or, perhaps, stereotypically) blog about rationality and live gender-fluid, polycurious lifestyles in group houses in Berkeley and Oakland.

SBF is from the Bay Area‚Äîthe eldest son of two Stanford law professors, Joe Bankman and Barbara Fried. His parents raised him and his siblings utilitarian‚Äîin the same way one might be brought up Unitarian‚Äîamid dinner-table debates about the greatest good for the greatest number. One of SBF‚Äôs formative moments came at age 12, when he was weighing arguments, pro and con, around the abortion debate. A rights-based theorist might argue that there aren‚Äôt really any discontinuous differences as a fetus becomes a child (and thus fetus murder is essentially child murder). The utilitarian argument compares the consequences of each. The loss of an actual child‚Äôs life‚Äîa life in which a great deal of parental and societal resources have been invested‚Äîis much more consequential than the loss of a potential life, in utero. And thus, to a utilitarian, abortion looks more like birth control than like murder. SBF‚Äôs application of utilitarianism helped him resolve some nagging doubts he had about the ethics of abortion. It made him comfortable being pro-choice‚Äîas his friends, family, and peers were. He saw the essential rightness of his philosophical faith.

Highly mathletic, SBF breezed through Crystal Springs Uplands, an elite prep school in Hillsborough, California. Though he earned top marks, he kept to himself, spending most of his free time playing computer games (StarCraft, League of Legends) and a trading card game, Magic: The Gathering. But at MIT he found his tribe: fellow pledges at Epsilon Theta, a coed fraternity of supergeeks similarly interested in Magic, and video games. Thetans are fond of debating math, physics, computer science, linguistics, philosophy and logic problems‚Äîfor fun‚Äîat alcohol-free parties.

It was his fellow Thetans who introduced SBF to EA and then to MacAskill, who was, at that point, still virtually unknown. MacAskill was visiting MIT in search of volunteers willing to sign on to his earn-to-give program. At a caf√© table in Cambridge, Massachusetts, MacAskill laid out his idea as if it were a business plan: a strategic investment with a return measured in human lives. The opportunity was big, MacAskill argued, because, in the developing world, life was still unconscionably cheap. Just do the math: At $2,000 per life, a million dollars could save 500 people, a billion could save half a million, and, by extension, a trillion could theoretically save half a billion humans from a miserable death.

MacAskill couldn‚Äôt have hoped for a better recruit. Not only was SBF raised in the Bay Area as a utilitarian, but he‚Äôd already been inspired by Peter Singer to take moral action. During his freshman year, SBF went vegan and organized a campaign against factory farming. As a junior, he was wondering what to do with his life. And MacAskill‚ÄîSinger‚Äôs philosophical heir‚Äîhad the answer: The best way for him to maximize good in the world would be to maximize his wealth.

SBF listened, nodding, as MacAskill made his pitch. The earn-to-give logic was airtight. It was, SBF realized, applied utilitarianism. Knowing what he had to do, SBF simply said, ‚ÄúYep. That makes sense.‚Äù But, right there, between a bright yellow sunshade and the crumb-strewn red-brick floor, SBF‚Äôs purpose in life was set: He was going to get filthy rich, for charity‚Äôs sake. All the rest was merely execution risk.

His course established, MacAskill gave SBF one last navigational nudge to set him on his way, suggesting that SBF get an internship at Jane Street that summer.

***

In 2017, everything was going great for SBF. He was killing it at Jane Street. He was a trader‚Äôs trader: so fluent with transactions that others would come watch him work, like one might watch an esports athlete streaming on Twitch. He was giving away 50 percent of his income to his preferred charities, with the biggest donations going to the Centre for Effective Altruism and 80,000 Hours. Both charities focus on building the earn-to-give idea into a movement. (And both had been founded by Will MacAskill a few years before.) He had good friends, mostly fellow EAs. Some were even colleagues. Jane Street was a great place to work, with an enviable corporate culture, plenty of perks, and some of the most generous pay packages in the industry. SBF had launched himself on a trajectory that would make him a very wealthy man. He was extremely happy at Jane Street‚Äîand content to stay there forever.

Still, when SBF analyzed the bright future that lay before him, something wasn‚Äôt right. He was, he realized, too secure. SBF‚Äôs mind had been trained almost from birth to calculate. As a schoolboy the hedonic calculous of utilitarianism had him trying to maximize the utility function (measured in ‚Äúutils,‚Äù of course) for abortion. During his teenage gaming years, his mathematical abilities allowed him to sharpen his tactics‚Äîand win. And, of course, every trade SBF ever made at Jane was the subject of a risk/reward calculation. All of it boiled down to expected value. The formula is fairly simple. If the amount won multiplied by the probability of winning a bet is greater than the amount lost multiplied by the probability of losing a bet, then you go for it‚Äîirrespective of units. Utils, euros, dollars were all subject to the same reckoning.

But, at Jane, SBF osmosed another trading principle. He learned to be ‚Äúrisk-neutral‚Äù: In simple terms, a trader, given a choice between $50 and a 50 percent chance at $100, must be agnostic if they want to maximize the expected value of earnings over a lifetime. Those who prefer the sure win are ‚Äúrisk-averse,‚Äù and those who would rather gamble are ‚Äúrisk-lovers.‚Äù But both risk-lovers and the risk-averse are suckers, equally. Because, over the long run, they lose out to the risk-neutral, who take both deals without prejudice.

Here, SBF realized, was the rub: When he applied this principle to his own life, he came up short. There was little chance he‚Äôd get himself fired from Jane Street. Thus the decision to stick with Jane was a risk-averse preference. It was the logical equivalent of being offered a choice between $50 and 50 percent of $100, and saying, ‚ÄúGive me President Grant.‚Äù SBF was risk-neutral on behalf of Jane Street, but not, he realized, for his own life. To be fully rational about maximizing his income on behalf of the poor, he should apply his trading principles across the board. He had to find a risk-neutral career path‚Äîwhich, if we strip away the trader-jargon, actually means he felt he needed to take on a lot more risk in the hopes of becoming part of the global elite. The math couldn‚Äôt be clearer. Very high risk multiplied by dynastic wealth trumps low risk multiplied by mere rich-guy wealth. To do the most good for the world, SBF needed to find a path on which he‚Äôd be a coin toss away from going totally bust.

Pressed on how he justified the decision to gamble with his future, SBF turns the question around, imagining a world where operating this way is commonplace. In that world, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a thousand of you. Some of you are going to do good, but the starving child doesn‚Äôt give a shit about which person it is who does that good. So why are you concerned about this little term in the equation?‚Äù To be clear: that ‚Äúlittle term‚Äù in SBF‚Äôs equation is ‚Äúyou‚Äù‚Äîin other words, the specific person who saves the starving child. SBF is making a distinction between the selfish desire to be a savior and the selfless desire that children be saved‚Äîand choosing selflessness. ‚ÄúObviously, I care about impact,‚Äù he says, and by ‚Äúimpact‚Äù he means ‚Äúmaximizing the overall chance that someone saves the child.‚Äù Thus, logically, it follows that ‚ÄúI am risk-neutral on overall impact.‚Äù

In the wake of this epiphany, SBF gave his notice. Caroline Ellison, a friend and colleague who was trading on the equities desk at Jane Street during that time, remembers the moment well. ‚ÄúIt was unusual,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúbecause he decided to quit‚Äînot to do anything in particular, but just under the premise that there were a lot of other options out there.‚Äù

SBF made a list of possible options, with some notes about each:

Journalism‚Äîlow pay, but a massively outsized impact potential. Running for office‚Äîor maybe just being an advisor? Working for the movement‚ÄîEA needs people! Starting a startup‚Äîbut what, exactly? Bumming around the Bay Area for a month or so‚Äîjust to see what happens.

‚ÄúThey all felt kind of compelling,‚Äù he remembers, ‚Äúand I had no idea which was going to be the best.‚Äù But he also knew that the only losing choice was to not make a choice, so he closed his eyes and walked through door number five.

That‚Äôs when Caroline Ellison lost track of her friend.

***

Ellison is a freckle-faced redhead with a personality that splits the difference between bubbly and nerd-ball. She‚Äôs partial to a pair of designer frames that make her look a bit like Edna Mode, the superhero stylist in The Incredibles.

About six months after SBF dropped out, Jane Street sent Ellison on a recruiting trip to California, so she decided to call on her old friend. They‚Äôd been office buddies at Jane, but they‚Äôd also occasionally socialized outside of work, too, being fellow EA acolytes. Ellison wanted to catch up, but from the get-go, SBF was acting uncharacteristically shifty. There were several canceled coffee dates, and when the two finally did get together‚Äîat Jumpin‚Äô Java, an old-school Berkeley coffeehouse with hand-painted murals on the wall and whimsical art in the windows‚ÄîSBF evaded even the most innocuous of questions.

caroline ellison dressed as a wood nymph for a larp

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù Ellison asked after joining SBF at a table, ‚Äúwhat have you been up to in the  last few months?‚Äù Ellison, it should be noted, was dressed as a sultry wood nymph‚Äîshe was on her way to a LARP (Live Action Role Play) party.

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù SBF responded cryptically, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tell you. It‚Äôs a secret.‚Äù

‚ÄúOkay, that‚Äôs fine,‚Äù Ellison said, sipping her tea.

Uncomfortable silence.

‚ÄúWell, I guess I could tell you if you really want‚Ä¶‚Äù SBF offered after a moment.

‚ÄúNope. It‚Äôs okay.‚Äù Sip.

An awkward beat later, SBF broke, slayed by the silent force of Ellison‚Äôs four-eyed gaze.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll just tell you,‚Äù he said.

The story was pretty remarkable. After SBF quit Jane Street, he moved back home to the Bay Area, where Will MacAskill had offered him a job as director of business development at the Centre for Effective Altruism. He rented a modest apartment near CEA HQ in Berkeley, he still had a couple of weeks to just explore before his job started. This was his first vacation in, well, ever. In the years working at Jane, SBF had never taken any significant time off.

He spent his vacation just soaking everything in: It was his first time in the Bay Area as an adult, and he found his home turf unexpectedly thrilling. It was where all the new technology was. It was where all the startups were. It was where the bulk of the EA community was starting to congregate. SBF ended up hanging out a lot with his younger brother Gabe, who was living in an EA commune on nearby Stuart Street.

At that time, everyone in the tech world was talking about crypto. In the Bay Area, you couldn‚Äôt escape the chatter. The crypto community had been roiled by a ‚Äúhard fork‚Äù earlier in the year, when what had been known simply as Bitcoin underwent a mitosis to become Bitcoin Classic and Bitcoin Cash. Later that year, Bitcoin (Classic) looked like it was going to cross the psychologically important $10,000 mark. Crypto was becoming a thing.

Curious, SBF had started looking into crypto‚Äîand almost immediately noticed something strange. Bitcoin was trading at a higher price in Japan and Korea than it was in the U.S. In theory, this should never happen because it represents a riskless profit opportunity‚Äîin other words, a free lunch. One simply buys Bitcoin at the lower price, sells it at the higher price, and pockets the difference. Jane Street built an empire on high-frequency trades that took advantage of fraction-of-a-cent price differences. But here was Bitcoin, trading at around $15,000 in South Korea: an unheard-of 50 percent price premium.

SBF was incredulous at the numbers he was seeing on his screen. This is probably not real. But then came the second thought: If it is real, then there‚Äôs $5,000 just lying on the ground. Instead of wasting time on internal debate, SBF decided to create some accounts on different exchanges and see if he could execute the trade. He couldn‚Äôt. But, interestingly, it wasn‚Äôt because the arbitrage opportunity wasn‚Äôt there‚Äîit was. But there was so much red tape with the banking system and currency controls that it was a difficult trade to execute.

Another day of work dealing with the red-tape problem netted SBF a single round-trip trade‚Äîto Asia and back‚Äîfor a $20 profit. That was it: the proof of concept. There was an opportunity to be had. SBF immediately put $50,000 of his own money to work. The first job was just getting the money into the system. The operational challenges were huge. Not just anyone can walk into a foreign bank and start wiring money out of the country every day. There are know-your-customer rules, caps on withdrawals, citizenship requirements. Even worse, to any normal bank, the constant zeroing out, then maxing out, of a cash account‚Äîwith the money coming and going overseas, to and from fly-by-night Bitcoin exchanges‚Äîraised every red flag in the book. It looked like laundering. It looked like drug money. There were even monetary policy concerns: The liquidity of the South Korean won is sharply limited by the country‚Äôs central bank.

Fortunately, SBF had a secret weapon: the EA community. There‚Äôs a loose worldwide network of like-minded people who do each other favors and sleep on each other‚Äôs couches simply because they all belong to the same tribe. Perhaps the most important of them was a Japanese grad student, who volunteered to do the legwork in Japan. As a Japanese citizen, he was able to open an account with the one (obscure, rural) Japanese bank that was willing, for a fee, to process the transactions that SBF‚Äînewly incorporated as Alameda Research‚Äîwanted to make. The spread between Bitcoin in Japan and Bitcoin in the U.S. was ‚Äúonly‚Äù 10 percent‚Äîbut it was a trade Alameda found it could make every day. With SBF‚Äôs initial $50,000 compounding at 10 percent each day, the next step was to increase the amount of capital. At the time, the total daily volume of crypto trading was on the order of a billion dollars. Figuring he wanted to capture 5 percent of that, SBF went looking for a $50 million loan. Again, he reached out to the EA community. Jaan Tallinn, the cofounder of Skype, put up a good chunk of that initial $50 million.

nishad singh in Nassau is compassionate to the core

With a goosed-up capital account, the money started piling up so fast that SBF placed what he refers to as ‚Äúa market order for employees‚Äù to tend to the Rube Goldberg operation that kept the capital spinning. There were constant blowups with banks, which are wary of anything crypto. Crypto was so new that regulators in South Korea and elsewhere were constantly changing their mind about regulations‚Äîthen making those changes retroactive. It was a swirling mess. Pulled into the vortex was Nishad Singh, a friend of SBF‚Äôs brother Gabe, and a fellow EA member. Singh is a bespectacled and baby-faced young man with an earnest mien. He often wears a T-shirt with the words ‚Äúcompassionate to the core‚Äù printed, in a diminutive all-lowercase font, over his heart. After just one conversation with SBF, Singh decided to leave Facebook to take on the more meaningful work of building FTX. Caroline Ellison came, too, quitting Jane Street and moving to California only weeks after SBF described the operation to her over tea. The first 15 people SBF hired, all from the EA pool, were packed together in a shabby, 600-square-foot walk-up, working around the clock. The kitchen was given over to stand-up desks, the closet was reserved for sleeping, and the entire space overrun with half-eaten take-out containers. It was a royal mess. But it was also the good old days, when Alameda was just kids on a high-stakes, big-money, earn-to-give commando operation. Fifty percent of Alameda‚Äôs profits were going to EA-approved charities.

‚ÄúThis thing couldn‚Äôt have taken off without EA,‚Äù reminisces Singh, running his hand through a shock of thick black hair. He removes his glasses to think. They‚Äôre broken: A chopstick has been Scotch taped to one of the frame‚Äôs sides, serving as a makeshift temple. ‚ÄúAll the employees, all the funding‚Äîeverything was EA to start with.‚Äù

***

The Bitcoin arbitrage didn‚Äôt‚Äîand couldn‚Äôt‚Äîlast forever. The Japanese appetite for overpriced Bitcoin withered (or, more likely, another shadowy arbitrage outfit also found its way to the trade and collapsed it). Either way, the spread narrowed to almost nothing. But there were other trades to be had. The simple fact that crypto was new, and that the tools traders needed to handle it were still under construction, meant that there were market inefficiencies all over the place. And behind every market inefficiency is an arbitrage opportunity.

The biggest headache for Alameda wasn‚Äôt finding the opportunities, but executing the trades. At that time, when it came to crypto exchanges, the choice basically boiled down to Coinbase or Binance. Coinbase makes a point of being regulated by authorities in the U.S., but as a consequence, didn‚Äôt offer the kinds of options contracts and derivatives professional traders need to hedge their bets. Binance, on the other hand, offered the kinds of derivatives SBF was familiar with when he traded for Jane Street‚Äîbut as a company, it was continually moving from country to country in an attempt to evade all jurisdictional authority. Neither exchange was particularly good to trade on.

‚ÄúEverything was rickety‚Äîthere was no avoiding the ricketiness. Obviously, the line between rickety and shady is a little unclear at times, but the places that seemed like they were going to steal customer funds outright, we didn‚Äôt touch,‚Äù Singh says. ‚ÄúEven the best players in the space were having big problems.‚Äù

At this point, mid-2019, SBF decided to double down again‚Äîand scratch his own itch. He would bet Alameda‚Äôs multimillion-dollar trading profits on a new venture: a trading exchange called FTX. It would combine Coinbase‚Äôs stolid, regulation-loving approach with the kinds of derivatives being offered by Binance and others. He only gave himself a 20 percent chance of success, but, in his mind, SBF needed extreme risk to maximize the expected value of his lifetime earnings‚Äîand, therefore, the good his earn-to-give strategy could do. The fact that he was, by his own lights, overwhelmingly likely to fail was beside the point.

The point was this: When SBF multiplied out the billions of dollars a year a successful crypto-trading exchange could throw off by his self-assessed 20 percent chance of successfully building one, the number was still huge. That‚Äôs the expected value. And if you live your life according to the same principles by which you‚Äôd trade an asset, there‚Äôs only one way forward: You calculate the expected values, then aim for the largest one‚Äîbecause, in one (but just one) alternate future universe, everything works out fabulously. To maximize your expected value, you must aim for it and then march blindly forth, acting as if the fabulously lucky SBF of the future can reach into the other, parallel, universes and compensate the failson SBFs for their losses. It sounds crazy, or perhaps even selfish‚Äîbut it‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs math. It follows from the principle of risk-neutrality.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs hard to justify being risk-averse on your own personal impact,‚Äù SBF told me when I quizzed him about it‚Äî‚Äúunless you‚Äôre doing it for personal reasons.‚Äù In other words, it‚Äôs selfish not to go for broke‚Äîif you‚Äôre planning on giving it all away in the end anyway.

And, with that, he moved the nascent company to Hong Kong, a jurisdiction with a crypto-friendly regulatory regime. Hong Kong also happens to be conveniently located next door to the country that, at the time, had the largest and most enthusiastic crypto user base in the world: China.

***

As Covid-19 descended, Michelle Bailhe, a young gun at Sequoia Capital, and veteran partner Alfred Lin were starting to closely examine the crypto space. Lin, a no-nonsense workaholic if there ever was one, had little patience for the kind of utopianism that motivated the first wave of cryptopians. Lin‚Äôs intellect was tempered in graduate school at Stanford, where he studied statistics and price options, swaps, and derivatives. And when he thought about crypto, the question he asked himself was: What is it good for? 

‚ÄúYes, crypto eventually could replace money, and, yes, it can eventually decentralize the web,‚Äù Lin says with a dismissive wave of his hand. ‚ÄúBut all those things are not true today. And, so, what is the thing that people do today? They trade. And if people trade, and people like trading, what is the business model that will make tons of money? It would be an exchange.‚Äù

Bailhe spent months researching the space full time, focusing her energies on the exchanges. She met with every founder and every company that would have her. And she built a map‚Äîa landscape, as such a document is called at Sequoia‚Äîof the entire market.

‚ÄúOf the exchanges that we had met and looked at, some of them had regulatory issues, some of them were already public,‚Äù Bailhe says. ‚ÄúAnd then there was Sam.‚Äù The exchange that SBF had started to build, FTX, was Goldilocks-perfect. There was no concerted effort to skirt the law, no Zuckerbergian diktat demanding that things be broken. And, yet, FTX wasn‚Äôt waiting to get permission to innovate. The company had based itself offshore precisely because it aspired to build an advanced risk engine that would support all sorts of hedging strategies. SBF himself seemed to be bred for the role of crypto exchange founder and CEO. Not only had he been a top trader at a top firm‚Äîand, thus, the ideal customer‚Äîbut both his parents were lawyers. ‚ÄúAnd, so, he is committed to making the right chess moves for FTX to eventually be able to legally do everything they want to do in the U.S.,‚Äù Bailhe says‚Äî‚Äúnot by asking forgiveness, but by asking permission.‚Äù

The problem, as Bailhe saw it, was that FTX didn‚Äôt appear to need any money. She was correct, but what she didn‚Äôt know was that SBF was starting to think about raising money anyway. Alameda had some unexpected losses due to so-called counterparty risk. Arbitrage is, in theory, riskless. But not when the rickety exchange you‚Äôre using to place your trades suddenly locks up and refuses to disburse your money. Or, worse yet, when two crypto exchanges can‚Äôt even agree on what a crypto transfer looks like, and so the act of sending crypto from one exchange to another results in tokens just disappearing into the ether. And don‚Äôt even ask about futures contracts that see their terms unilaterally changed mid-agreement: the dreaded ‚Äúclawbacks.‚Äù Alameda was not immune to the exchange-level shenanigans that gave crypto as a whole its sleazy reputation. But FTX had an ambition to change that. It was built to be the exchange traders could count on. SBF needed to get the word out. He wanted FTX to be known as the respectable face of crypto. This required ad campaigns, sponsorship deals, a charitable wing‚Äîand a war chest to pay for it all. 

FTX did need money, after all. And it needed that money from credible sources so it could continue to distinguish itself from the bottom-feeders who came to crypto to fleece the suckers. So, in the summer of 2021, when FTX started to raise its Series B from a who‚Äôs who of Silicon Valley VCs, Bailhe and Lin hit the ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Panic‚Äù button. ‚ÄúEmbarrassingly, we had never tried to reach out to Sam, because we figured he didn‚Äôt need us,‚Äù Bailhe admits. ‚ÄúI thought they were just minting money and had absolutely no need for investors.‚Äù Learning otherwise, they quickly contacted SBF and organized a last-minute Zoom call between him and the partners at Sequoia‚Äîat four California time on a hot July Friday afternoon. Bailhe was adamant, putting her reputation with the other partners on the line: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòNo, it‚Äôs worth it. Cancel your afternoon.‚Äô‚Äù

The Zoom went well for all concerned. SBF looked relaxed as he answered questions, talking, as he usually does, in complete paragraphs about topics of extreme complexity. Ramnik Arora, FTX‚Äôs head of product and another ex-Facebook engineer, remembers the meeting clearly: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre getting all these questions from Sequoia toward the end. He‚Äôs absolutely fantastic.‚Äù Arora locks eyes with me, and I am mesmerized. Arora is intense‚Äîcalling to mind a Bollywood version of Adrian Brody. ‚ÄúUnbelievably fantastic,‚Äù he says, shaking his head.

Bailhe remembers it the same way: ‚ÄúWe had a great meeting with Sam, but the last question, which I remember Alfred asking, was, ‚ÄòSo, everything you‚Äôre building is great, but what is your long-term vision for FTX?‚Äô‚Äù

That‚Äôs when SBF told Sequoia about the so-called super-app: ‚ÄúI want FTX to be a place where you can do anything you want with your next dollar. You can buy bitcoin. You can send money in whatever currency to any friend anywhere in the world. You can buy a banana. You can do anything you want with your money from inside FTX.‚Äù

Suddenly, the chat window on Sequoia‚Äôs side of the Zoom lights up with partners freaking out.

‚ÄúI LOVE THIS FOUNDER,‚Äù typed one partner.

‚ÄúI am a 10 out of 10,‚Äù pinged another. 

‚ÄúYES!!!‚Äù exclaimed a third.

What Sequoia was reacting to was the scale of SBF‚Äôs vision. It wasn‚Äôt a story about how we might use fintech in the future, or crypto, or a new kind of bank. It was a vision about the future of money itself‚Äîwith a total addressable market of every person on the entire planet.

‚ÄúI sit ten feet from him, and I walked over, thinking, Oh, shit, that was really good,‚Äù remembers Arora. ‚ÄúAnd it turns out that that fucker was playing League of Legends through the entire meeting.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were incredibly impressed,‚Äù Bailhe says. ‚ÄúIt was one of those your-hair-is-blown-back type of meetings.‚Äù 

Not only that, Arora says, but League of Legends is the kind of multiplayer online battle arena video game where every four minutes or so of tactical maneuvering is punctuated by ten seconds of action known as a gank‚Äîgamer slang for ‚Äúgang killing‚Äù‚Äîwhere you and your team gang up on an enemy. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a fight that happens, basically,‚Äù says Arora, who was watching over SBF‚Äôs shoulder as he answered that final question from Sequoia, ‚Äúand I‚Äôm like, This guy is fucking in a gank!‚Äù

The B round raised a billion dollars. Soon afterward came the ‚Äúmeme round‚Äù: $420.69 million from 69 investors.

***

SBF took the money, and soon after moved FTX headquarters from Hong Kong to Nassau. Covid-19 was raging, and the city‚Äôs Beijing-inspired zero-Covid policy was making business in Hong Kong untenable. The Bahamas had more relaxed Covid rules and are only 20 minutes away by plane from the crypto industry that was starting to coalesce around Miami.

I fly out to see the company for myself in the spring of 2022. Walking through the terminal in Nassau, I happen to see a copy of The New York Times. The headline on the front page says it all: ‚ÄúAs Cryptocurrencies Melt Down, $300 Billion Evaporates in Days.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a survey of what‚Äôs been happening in the crypto market. The price of Bitcoin had plunged to its lowest level since 2020. A so-called ‚Äústable coin‚Äù lost its peg and became worthless overnight. The price of Coinbase shares, a publicly traded rival of FTX‚Äôs, collapsed. The markets were in mayhem.

Next to the Times is a copy of The Nassau Guardian: Hurricane warnings, a record Omicron surge. This ought to be an interesting week, I think to myself.

***

‚ÄúFew could stand by and watch a child drown; many can ignore the avoidable deaths of children in Africa or India. The question, however, is not what we usually do, but what we ought to do.‚Äù

philosopher Peter Singer

But both risk-lovers and the risk-averse are suckers, equally. Because, over the long run, they lose out to the risk-neutral, who take both deals without prejudice.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a thousand of you. Some of you are going to do good, but the starving child doesn‚Äôt give a shit about which person it is who does that good. So why are you concerned about this little term in the equation?‚Äù

sam bankman-fried

SBF was incredulous at the numbers he was seeing on his screen. This is probably not real. But then came the second thought: If it is real, then there‚Äôs $5,000 just lying on the ground.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs hard to justify being risk-averse on your own personal impact, unless you‚Äôre doing it for personal reasons.‚Äù

sam bankman-fried

‚ÄúYes, crypto eventually could replace money, and, yes, it can eventually decentralize the web. But all those things are not true today. And, so, what is the thing that people do today? They trade.‚Äù

alfred lin

‚ÄúOf the exchanges that we had met and looked at, some of them had regulatory issues, some of them were already public. And then there was Sam.‚Äù

michelle Bailhe

The following Monday, I brave the flooded roads of New Providence to the FTX campus. It‚Äôs a Walmart-sized parking lot hacked out of the canebrake. FTX operations are housed in five 2,000-square-foot stucco-walled and steel-roofed pavilions: identical structures so new they look as if they‚Äôve popped out of the parking lot like mushrooms after a rain.

The HQ building is distinguished by a reception desk in the microscopic lobby. The door is unlocked. There is no receptionist. I peek around the corner and into the FTX command center‚Äî29 desks in a room designed to hold 8, at most. Every desk touches two or three others. There are no aisles. To get across the room, you have to wade through (and, at times, climb over) a sea of office chairs. Walls of wide-screen monitors‚Äîtwo, four, even six per desk‚Äîstand in place of cubicle walls. The screens erupt like palm leaves from aluminum uprights and are oriented willy-nilly: up, down, sideways. Some screens are mounted so high they seem to hang down from the ceiling. It‚Äôs office environment as jungle, and the oddest thing about it is that no one seems to be home.

Then I hear a rustling. A nasal NorCal drawl rings out from the far corner of the room: ‚ÄúYup‚Ä¶ Yup‚Ä¶ Yup‚Ä¶‚Äù Giggle. ‚ÄúOh, totally.‚Äù

It‚Äôs SBF himself, working early‚Äîor late, as the case may be. I recognize the man because right beside his desk is a giant blue-velvet beanbag chair, which SBF famously uses as a napping spot during the weeks-long work binges when he doesn‚Äôt leave the office.

He‚Äôs on a Zoom call. And, from what I can overhear, he‚Äôs chatting with someone about acquiring shares of a competitor ‚ÄúHow much do we have? How much can we buy? How much are we legally allowed to buy?‚Äù

It sounds like an important strategic conversation, and SBF‚Äôs questions come rat-a-tat with an overclocked diction I recognize from listening to too many podcasts at 2X. Yet, in the middle of it, he peers around his sheaf of liquid crystal to silently greet me with a big smile and an outstretched right hand while simultaneously making a wavy-pointy gesture with his left, which means ‚ÄúHave a seat over yonder.‚Äù He‚Äôs nothing if not efficient.

Over the next hour or so, people trickle in, and the room fills up. They‚Äôre all friendly, but also focused. They seem to be used to having a stranger in their midst. Word comes that there‚Äôs an all-hands meeting scheduled, and I‚Äôm invited. To my surprise, it turns out to be on Zoom‚Äîeven though half the assembled audience is within ten feet of SBF. At the appointed hour, everyone switches on their screens and adjusts their cameras. SBF appears in the corner of the Zoom grid to talk about the situation at hand.

To sum up, much of the crypto world was panic-selling to try to get out ahead of the market, to make a margin call, or just out of plain old fear. And that volume hit FTX, since it‚Äôs a major exchange‚Äîthe fifth-largest‚Äîin the crypto space. There‚Äôs really no good way to simulate such an event, but FTX‚Äôs trading platform held together under the strain. So SBF‚Äôs first order of business is to congratulate the dev crew for building a robust system: ‚ÄúOverall, I think the platform handled the crash relatively well, which is good. Thank you to everyone.‚Äù

There are some modest smiles in the Zoom windows, including one from Singh, FTX‚Äôs director of engineering. He knows firsthand, from his trading days at Alameda, how frustrating a rickety exchange can be. ‚ÄúAs always, we have some changes to make going forward,‚Äù SBF says, ‚Äúbut nothing really huge.‚Äù The next order of business is a round of belt-tightening. ‚ÄúIn general, money is going to be tighter for everyone in our industry and other industries too‚Äîit‚Äôs not super-crypto-specific,‚Äù SBF says. ‚ÄúSo, if you are thinking about expenses that are, say, above $100 million, we should have a chat about that,‚Äù he continues. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs our new set of takeaways,‚Äù he says, wrapping up his portion of the meeting. ‚ÄúOh, and yeah: Ten-second updates!‚Äù

With that, the floor is open. And indeed, various FTX execs take over the presenters‚Äô mic, updating the company, in ten seconds or less, about what is going on.

FTX Stocks is now open for a private beta. An independent FTX fan club has emerged: the FTT DAO. Time-weighted average price functionality is being tested. The sponsorship deals of the Met Gala and the amfAR Gala have been successful‚Äîso far. The NBA Eastern Conference final starts tonight at the FTX Arena: the Miami Heat versus the Boston Celtics.

That last item is the only one that provokes any kind of comment from SBF: ‚ÄúGo, Heat!‚Äù he shouts.

All-hands adjourned. Total meeting time? Ten minutes.

I remark to the person sitting next to me that that was rather quick for an all-hands. ‚ÄúThat was actually an unusually long one,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre usually five minutes.‚Äù

***

I‚Äôm embedded in FTX headquarters‚Äîa reporter sitting at a desk ten feet away from SBF‚Äîfor a full week. I interview people, take notes, hang out, and soak up the vibe. I was expecting pandemonium in the wake of the market collapse, but the atmosphere is almost relaxed‚Äîexcept for the fact that SBF just keeps working and working. He‚Äôs working when people arrive. He‚Äôs working when people leave. It‚Äôs Zoom after Zoom after Zoom, and, because SBF wears a headset, he‚Äôs literally plugged into his computer all day. The only time I ever see him unplug is to collapse on that supersized beanbag chair next to his desk for a catnap. 

SBF napping in Nassau

At first blush, the scene is classic startup‚Äîthe kitchen full of snacks and soda; the free catered breakfasts, lunches, and dinners; the company bathroom stocked with everything you‚Äôd need to actually live at the office: Q-tips, disposable razors, Kotex. In keeping with the fashion aesthetic of senior management, the dress code is marketing-swag-meets-utilitarian-merch: gift-bag T-shirts featuring the FTX logo, nylon athletic shorts, white-cotton gym socks.

But, as the week wears on, it‚Äôs the differences that start to stand out. FTX is not your ordinary startup. Most noticeable is the average age of the employees. Among senior management, SBF himself has just turned 30; Singh is 28; Arora is the old man of the group at 35. The company is also remarkably international. You hear the rapid-fire rhythm of Mandarin as often as English, but even that lingua franca comes in a wide variety of flavors‚Äîeverything from a Bahamian lilt to the broken argot of ESL.

I often step out of the pressure cooker of FTX HQ and into the frying pan of the company parking lot‚Äîa macadam patch that fairly sizzles under the Bahamian sun‚Äîin order to stretch my legs. I meet a bunch of FTX employees that way. They‚Äôre taking walks, too. In general, the people I meet are overworked but happy. A few are overworked and unhappy‚Äîor at least too busy to be able to enjoy their good fortune. To a person, they‚Äôre unfailingly polite and helpful. FTX has a remarkable corporate culture, and, like the fashion choices on display, that comes right from the top. There‚Äôs a guilelessness, an openness, that makes for interesting conversations.

Can Sun, FTX‚Äôs in-house legal counsel, tells me that his main job is to cement the many deals SBF makes on a handshake. Ninety-nine times out of a hundred, Sun says, the terms favor the other side. It‚Äôs another corporate policy derived from a rigorous logical argument: In an iterated prisoner‚Äôs dilemma, the best first move is always to cooperate. And, if the counterparty defects, ‚Äúit‚Äôs better that I know this guy will screw me over now,‚Äù Sun says, ‚Äúrather than later.‚Äù

A woman who helps run marketing for FTX (and who prefers to be anonymous), briefs me on the Crypto Bahamas event that took place the previous month. Tony Blair and Bill Clinton showed up, as did Michael Lewis, Katy Perry and Orlando Bloom. Her mission is to try to broaden the brand‚Äôs appeal. ‚ÄúWhen I first joined, we had endorsement deals with Tom Brady, Steph Curry, Major League Baseball‚Äîit was like a frat house,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we signed the Naomi Osaka deal.‚Äù

Adam Jin, who‚Äôs in charge of strategic investments for FTX, tells me about one of his favorite Web3 projects, a health app called STEPN that comes with its own crypto wallet. ‚ÄúOnce you download the app, you go to the marketplace and buy shoes,‚Äù Jin says, showing me his shoes‚Äîvirtual sneakers‚Äîon the STEPN app. Jin must sense my confusion because he continues: ‚ÄúYou can use the app without the shoes, but having the shoes will entitle you to earn tokens by walking around.‚Äù

STEPN is an example of the hottest new trend in crypto: the ‚Äúplay-to-earn‚Äù game. With STEPN, you have to make an upfront investment. Jin‚Äôs virtual shoes cost him $800 (although he paid in Sol, the cryptocurrency associated with the Solana network.) But Jin can get a return on his shoe investment by walking: STEPN will pay him back, in crypto naturally, for every kilometer he walks in them. The exact ROI depends on the ever-fluctuating rates between Sol and the STEPN in-game currency, as well as on shoe-maintenance costs. (I‚Äôm surprised to learn that virtual shoes do wear out and have to be replaced.) But focusing on what it takes to win the game is missing the point, according to Jin. ‚ÄúIt changed my lifestyle,‚Äù he says, noting that he‚Äôs lost all of his pandemic weight since he started using the app: ‚ÄúI went five kilometers on my lunch break yesterday‚Äîjust running around and being healthy.‚Äù

I kind of get it. STEPN adds motivation, in the form of money, to the usual boatload of reasons people have for getting fit. And, for some people, that‚Äôs the motivation they need to get out there and start exercising. Is this the killer app for crypto? I‚Äôm skeptical‚Äîuntil, several days later, the truth finally dawns on me. It‚Äôs not just Jin: Many‚Äîperhaps most‚Äîof the FTX employees I meet while walking around the parking lot are not simply on break, stretching their legs. They‚Äôre earning crypto, through their STEPN app.

At first I assumed that only the financial types who work in crypto could possibly be motivated by such convoluted carrots. But the FOMO hit me at about the same time that I realized that everyone except me was wearing invisible sneakers. I find myself‚Äîa non-financial type if there ever was one‚Äîgetting drawn by the funny math of play-to-earn.

‚ÄúAdam,‚Äù I say, intercepting Jin on one of his five-kilometer lunch walks, ‚Äúsince the STEPN app uses the GPS on your phone to track your movement, couldn‚Äôt I just give my phone to someone else to take my walks for me?‚Äù

Jin catches my drift without losing his stride. ‚ÄúSure! You could pay someone 20 bucks to take your phone,‚Äù he says with a cheery agreeableness I now recognize as an FTX thing. ‚ÄúAnd then you would get paid for their steps.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt could be a good arb,‚Äù I observe.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd get more healthy that way, too,‚Äù says Jin with a chuckle.

***

I clock in at FTX HQ at nine and clock out at five for most of the week‚Äîuntil, one day, I‚Äôm invited to live in what amounts to the FTX dorms. Many employees take advantage of subsidized corporate housing at a nearby development called Albany. The heart of the development is a yacht basin and marina surrounded by half a dozen residential towers. The area is so new that several towers are still under construction. FTX owns a passel of the multi-bedroom apartments in the towers and rents them out as crash pads to employees. There‚Äôs a collegiate feel to the whole setup. Indeed, Albany could be mistaken for an institution of higher learning: Behind the gatehouse is everything you could ever ask for on a campus‚Äîrestaurants, caf√©s, a health club, golf and tennis facilities and, of course, classrooms.

And what a campus! Albany is one of the most stunningly gorgeous places I‚Äôve ever set foot in. The boat basin is filled with superyachts, megayachts, even a glittering gigayacht or two. The apartment towers that look down at the yachts below are, if it‚Äôs even possible, more immaculate than the boats. Befitting ‚Äúserious architecture,‚Äù the buildings aren‚Äôt numbered but named: Squire, Tetris, Cube, Honeycomb, Lantern, Charles, Gemini, Orchid. Each was designed by a starchitect of note: Manhattan‚Äôs Morris Adjmi, the noted postmodernist, did two. The community markets itself as a second-home destination for wealthy young people‚Äîin other words, for pro athletes and pop stars. Cardi B has a place here, as does Steph Curry. Justin Timberlake and Tiger Woods are, nominally, the developers of the property. So perhaps it‚Äôs not surprising that the Albany amenity package includes a top-notch sports-training facility (with the only cryotherapy chamber in the Bahamas), as well as a state-of-the-art recording studio.

I‚Äôm quartered in an FTX-owned Tetris condo for a few nights. Each of the four bedrooms has an en suite bath, its own climate control and a stout panel door with its own lock and key‚Äîfeatures that make each of the bedrooms feel like small hotel rooms. The common area is fronted with 26-foot-high glass walls that slide away to reveal a commanding balcony, complete with a sunken infinity edge pool. The kitchen is worthy of a private chef, and fully stocked (although, from the looks of it, no one has ever cooked a meal in it.)

As I fry up an omelet for myself‚Äîwith an egg of uncertain age‚Äîmy thoughts drift until they shoal in the lee of The Great Gatsby. The peerless American novel, written a century ago, seems especially relevant to the here and now: The Roaring Twenties are back, certainly. And I‚Äôll be damned if Albany is not West Egg. But is crypto the new jazz? And, if it is, does that make Sam Bankman-Fried the new Jay Gatsby? Both are very young; both are self-made; in inflation-adjusted dollars, both are equally wealthy; and both are enigmatic in the extreme. On the other hand, the differences between Jay Gatsby and SBF are vast. Literary types still argue about just what motivates F. Scott Fitzgerald‚Äôs most memorable character‚Äîbut one thing is certain: Altruism, effective or not, is not a factor. So, while SBF may be Gatsbian in some important ways, he‚Äôs no Gatsby. Still, I wonder if there isn‚Äôt a deeper resonance. A literary type myself, as I tuck into my solo meal, I find the novel‚Äôs closing lines tiptoeing into my consciousness:

Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that‚Äôs no matter‚Äîtomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther. . . . And one fine morning‚Äî

So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

***

meanwhile, FTX is hard at work‚Ä¶

I recognize the man because right beside his desk is a giant blue-velvet beanbag chair, which SBF famously uses as a napping spot during the weeks-long work binges when he doesn‚Äôt leave the office.

not as comfortable as a beanbag

The next day, I finally get a chance to interview Sam Bankman-Fried. We meet in a tiny conference room. I‚Äôm prepared with a mic and an MP3 recorder at the ready. SBF comes in with his laptop and opens it to start playing his new favorite computer game, Storybook Brawl, before he even sits down. It‚Äôs an obscure title, an ‚Äúauto-battler‚Äù: an emerging genre that combines elements of trading card games (like Magic: The Gathering) with chesslike moves and strategy. The game was released only a few years ago by an equally obscure low-budget ‚Äúindie‚Äù game company, Good Luck Games.

Though we‚Äôre face-to-face, SBF makes no eye contact at all‚Äîzero, not even a glance. His eyes are glued to his screen. His fingers are tapping on the keys, sometimes furiously, sometimes hardly at all. His right knee is bouncing at 100 bpm: a nervous tic, the result of a forgotten fidget spinner. The interview starts.

I open with a doozy: ‚ÄúAm I,‚Äù I ask, ‚Äútalking to the world‚Äôs first trillionaire?‚Äù

Although it‚Äôs admittedly a stupid question, it‚Äôs not as stupid as it sounds. SBF has a net worth, as estimated by Forbes, that‚Äôs higher than the vast majority (80 percent) of the world‚Äôs billionaires‚Äîand, yet, he‚Äôs only gotten started. FTX is a company in its infancy.

I first tried out the trillionaire question on Michelle Bailhe, the Sequoia partner who, along with Lin, knows SBF and his company the best. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a juicy question,‚Äù she said, wavering for a moment while calculating the odds. ‚ÄúI think he has a real chance at that.‚Äù

There‚Äôs no such hesitation from SBF. But he does quickly demur, making self-deprecating mouth noises questioning his own capacity to make such a pile, before he really starts to answer.

‚ÄúMaybe let‚Äôs take a step back,‚Äù he says, only to launch into an explanation of his own, personal utility curve: ‚ÄúWhich is to say, if you plot dollars-donated on the X axis, and Y is how-much-good-I-do-in-the-world, then what does that curve look like? It‚Äôs definitely not linear‚Äîit does tail off, but I think it tails off pretty slowly.‚Äù

His point seems to be that there is, out there somewhere, a diminishing return to charity. There‚Äôs a place where even effective altruism ceases to be effective. ‚ÄúBut I think that, even at a trillion, there‚Äôs still really significant marginal utility to dollars donated.‚Äù

This interview has morphed into my own personal economics seminar, and Professor Bankman-Fried is my tutor. He‚Äôs as good at explaining the principles of macroeconomics as anyone out there in the world today‚Äîand I know this for a fact because I‚Äôve subsequently watched YouTube‚Äôs best on the same subject. But SBF teaches me Macro while simultaneously playing round after round of Storybook Brawl.

Still, I‚Äôve got my answer. And it turns out that I‚Äôve aimed too low. A trillion isn‚Äôt enough money to fix the world‚Äôs problems, so SBF won‚Äôt stop at merely a trillion. It‚Äôs an answer that begs the next question, which SBF, ever helpful, has already anticipated: ‚ÄúSo, is five trillion all you could ever use to help the world?‚Äù

SBF is now interviewing himself. He slows down for a moment, and I assume that‚Äôs because of the cognitive load of doing three things at once. He‚Äôs asking good questions (my job); he‚Äôs formulating answers (his job); and he‚Äôs playing Storybook Brawl (no one‚Äôs job). But then I hear the tap-tap-tapping from his fingers start to accelerate, and I realize he‚Äôs not slowing down under the load at all. Just the opposite, in fact: This guy is in the Storybook Brawl equivalent of a gank!

And, just like that, he‚Äôs back with an answer to his own question: ‚ÄúOkay, at that scale, I think the answer might be yes. Because, if your spending is on the scale of the U.S. government, it might have too weird and distortionary an impact on things.‚Äù

Now that we‚Äôve explored the far end of SBF‚Äôs utility curve, the seminar moves to a discussion of discount rates. ‚ÄúThe world is decaying at‚Äîwe‚Äôre all making it up‚Äîbut, say, 5 percent a year as a minimum bound,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnd compare that to the effective interest rate which I‚Äôm working under‚Äîwhich you can think of as the rate we can turn more capital into more capital‚Äîwhich is more like 20 percent a year,‚Äù he continues, ‚Äúand that‚Äôs likely true for a while, so it makes sense for me to keep working.‚Äù

All this is still with not even a glance at me‚Äîhis true focus is on the screen. He‚Äôs playing the video game. But, to be fair, perhaps ‚Äúplaying‚Äù is the wrong word here. Perhaps he was play-testing: looking for ways to incorporate crypto into his favorite game because, unbeknownst to me at the time, as we were talking, Good Luck, the indie game company behind Storybook Brawl, was being absorbed into the FTX empire‚Äîthe latest in a string of FTX acquisitions.

‚ÄúBut that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt also be giving during that time,‚Äù he continues. ‚ÄúAnd we are starting to scale that up.‚Äù

This strikes me as typical SBF understatement. The scale of his giving, even now, before he has really started to divest, is massive. Alameda Research, the company that generated the FTX grubstake, still exists, and its purpose seems to be to generate profits‚Äîon the order of $100 million a year today, but potentially up to a billion‚Äîthat can be stuffed into the brand-new FTX Foundation. Similarly, even now, 1 percent of net FTX fees are donated to that same foundation, and FTX handles nearly $5 billion dollars‚Äô worth of trades per day. The foundation, in turn, gives to a diversified group of EA-approved charities. 

As you might expect, having read this far, there‚Äôs a reason for doling out some cash now instead of doubling down in the expectation of giving more later, and the reason hinges on math. Simply put, there are aspects of the world, as SBF sees it, that are decaying faster than 20 percent a year‚Äîand, so, money spent now will be more effective at making the world a better place than money spent later. ‚ÄúI think there are some things that are pretty urgent,‚Äù SBF says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs just a long series of crucial considerations, and all of them matter a lot‚Äîand you can‚Äôt fuck any of them up, or you miss most of the total value that you could ever get.‚Äù

To be clear, SBF is not talking about maximizing the total value of FTX‚Äîhe‚Äôs talking about maximizing the total value of the universe. And his units are not dollars: In a kind of GDP for the universe, his units are the units of a utilitarian. He‚Äôs maximizing utils, units of happiness. And not just for every living soul, but also every soul‚Äîhuman and animal‚Äîthat will ever live in the future. Maximizing the total happiness of the future‚Äîthat‚Äôs SBF‚Äôs ultimate goal. FTX is just a means to that end.

But, back to the now-things you can‚Äôt fuck up‚Äîthe tipping points. SBF ticks off his list:

‚ÄúWhen we build super-powerful AI, it‚Äôs likely to be one of the points where, all of a sudden, what we do will matter a lot.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe should start thinking about how to prepare for the next pandemic now, before it comes‚Äîbecause, at some point, it‚Äôs just going to come.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think we might be at a tipping point right now for U.S. politics. It matters a lot what we do over the next, say, two to ten years. Right?‚Äù

And, indeed, SBFputs his money where his mouth is. SBF is personally backing a slew of so-called AI alignment nonprofits and public-benefit corporations including Anthropic and Conjecture. He‚Äôs also the big money behind a new nonprofit called Guarding Against Pandemics, which, not coincidentally, is run by his brother Gabe. And SBF was the second-largest donor‚Äîbehind only Mike Bloomberg‚Äîfor Biden‚Äôs successful attempt to dethrone Trump.

With SBF doing the hard work of interviewing himself, I‚Äôm free to think. And, finally, just as the clock is running out on my allotted hour, I ask what might be the first non-stupid question of the entire interview.

‚ÄúSo,‚Äù I summarize, ‚Äúyou are young and vital and peaking at precisely the point where the world is at, as you see it, peak crisis.‚Äù SBF nods in agreement, deep in another round of Storybook Brawl. ‚ÄúDoes that strike you as just a lucky coincidence, or does that strike you as perhaps a signal that your thinking is flawed and you have a savior complex?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an interesting question,‚Äù he says, stalling.

I double down: ‚ÄúYou just happen to be alive in the most important time in the history of the future race. The existential point! Really?‚Äù

SBF hedges: ‚ÄúIt certainly would not be one‚Äôs prior‚Äîat least, not naively.‚Äù

‚ÄúPrior‚Äù‚Äîthat‚Äôs a term of art. There‚Äôs more math to explain (in this case, Bayes‚Äô theorem), but in the interest of you, dear reader, I will skip it.

‚ÄúBut,‚Äù SBF continues, ‚Äúif you want to really needle on that, there are some anthropic considerations by which that might not be as crazy as it sounds.‚Äù With the mention of ‚Äúanthropic‚Äù we‚Äôve reached conversational escape velocity and head into the nosebleed regions of modern metaphysics. Again, I‚Äôll spare you the trouble. Suffice it to say that, while SBF is willing to consider the idea that he might be delusional, as a kind of thought experiment, he ultimately dismisses it.

Game over.

***

After my interview with SBF, I was convinced: I was talking to a future trillionaire. Whatever mojo he worked on the partners at Sequoia‚Äîwho fell for him after one Zoom‚Äîhad worked on me, too. For me, it was simply a gut feeling. I‚Äôve been talking to founders and doing deep dives into technology companies for decades. It‚Äôs been my entire professional life as a writer. And because of that experience, there must be a pattern-matching algorithm churning away somewhere in my subconscious. I don‚Äôt know how I know, I just do. SBF is a winner.

But that wasn‚Äôt even the main thing. There was something else I felt: something in my heart, not just my gut. After sitting ten feet from him for most of the week, studying him in the human musk of the startup grind and chatting in between beanbag naps, I couldn‚Äôt shake the feeling that this guy is actually as selfless as he claims to be.

So I find myself convinced that, if SBF can keep his wits about him in the years ahead, he‚Äôs going to slay‚Äîthat, just as Alameda was a stepping stone to FTX, FTX will be to the super-app. Banking will be disrupted and transformed by crypto, just as media was transformed and disrupted by the web. Something of the sort must happen eventually, as the current system, with its layers upon layers of intermediaries, is antiquated and prone to crashing‚Äîthe global financial crisis of 2008 was just the latest in a long line of failures that occurred because banks didn‚Äôt actually know what was on their balance sheets. Crypto is money that can audit itself, no accountant or bookkeeper needed, and thus a financial system with the blockchain built in can, in theory, cut out most of the financial middlemen, to the advantage of all. Of course, that‚Äôs the pitch of every crypto company out there. The FTX competitive advantage? Ethical behavior. SBF is a Peter Singer‚Äìinspired utilitarian in a sea of Robert Nozick‚Äìinspired libertarians. He‚Äôs an ethical maximalist in an industry that‚Äôs overwhelmingly populated with ethical minimalists. I‚Äôm a Nozick man myself, but I know who I‚Äôd rather trust my money with: SBF, hands-down. And if he does end up saving the world as a side effect of being my banker, all the better.

‚ÄúIf you plot dollars-donated on the X axis, and Y is how-much-good-I-do-in-the-world, then what does that curve look like? It‚Äôs definitely not linear‚Äîit does tail off, but I think it tails off pretty slowly. But I think that, even at a trillion, there‚Äôs still really significant marginal utility to dollars donated.‚Äù

sam bankman-fried

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs just a long series of crucial considerations, and all of them matter a lot‚Äîand you can‚Äôt fuck any of them up, or you miss most of the total value that you could ever get.‚Äù

sam bankman-fried
JOIN OUR MAILING LIST Since you‚Äôve read this far, maybe you want even more? Email address Leave this field empty if you‚Äôre human:

As the success of FTX seems like a foregone conclusion, my interest gravitates to SBF the person. He‚Äôs like no other billionaire I‚Äôve ever met, and I‚Äôve hung out with quite a few. It‚Äôs like the brain of Spock has been transplanted into the shambolic body of Fozzie Bear.
